page.syntax: P a5_html_modal([C html_code [,C dlg_title [,L show_source_tab [,L read_only [,N width [,N height [,C event_handler_code [,C toolbar_layout [,C initial_path [,L flagStripBodyTagInSource ]]]]]]]]]])

argument.name: html_code
argument.description: Optional. Default = "". The HTML code of the page to be initially loaded into the editor upon launch.

argument.name: dlg_title
argument.description: Optional. Defaults = "HTML Editor". The dialog title of the window to be opened.

argument.name: show_source_tab
argument.description: Logical. Optional. Default = .T. A flag to control whether or not the editor should have a Source code tab.

argument.name: read_only
argument.description: Logical. Optional. Default = .F. A flag to disallow editing of the displayed HTML.

argument.name: width
argument.description: Numeric. Optional. Default = 110 (modal), 90 (modeless). Width of the HTML control in characters within the window.

argument.name: height
argument.description: Numeric. Optional. Default = 10 (modal), 5 (modeless). Height of the HTML control in lines within the window.

argument.name: event_handler_code
argument.description: Character. Optional. The name of the function handling events.

page.description: Opens a modal HTML Editor window
page.discussion: The A5_HTML_MODAL() function opens a generic modal dialog containing an HTML editing control. They can be used as-is, but are particularly useful for use as embedded dialogs Limitations: Desktop applications only.

section.description: This example opens the HTML editor shown in the picture below.
section.example: dim cc as C cc = "A5_HTML_EDITOR() " cc = cc + "A5_HTML_EDITOR() Syntax " cc = cc + "A5_HTML_EDITOR( Tabname as C, " cc = cc + "HTML_Text as C ) " a5_html_modal(cc, "My Editor")
